title_en: Young doctors enter into negotiations with the government in an attempt to end the salary dispute
summary_en:
Junior doctors in England are negotiating with the government to end a wage dispute after a series of mass strikes.
The British Medical Association has agreed to an intensive phase of negotiations with an external mediator.
Doctors' strikes have hampered efforts to reduce waiting lists in the National Health Service.
The Ministry of Health and Social Security considers this step to be a significant step forward that can end the strikes.
Doctors insist on restoring real wages to the level of 2008.
Since the beginning of the conflict, junior doctors have held 10 rounds of strikes, and 98% voted in favor of continuing the strike.
The agreement between the BMA and the Government on mediation is a positive step after a period of relative calm.
The heads of the National Health Service and patients hope for a solution to the problem.

title: –ü—Ä–æ—Ñ—Å–æ—é–∑—ã –ù–∞—á–Ω—É—Ç –ü—Ä–æ—Ç–µ—Å—Ç–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å –í –ü–æ–Ω–µ–¥–µ–ª—å–Ω–∏–∫ –ü—Ä–æ—Ç–∏–≤ –ü–æ–≤—ã—à–µ–Ω–∏—è –¢–∞—Ä–∏—Ñ–æ–≤ –ù–∞ –≠–ª–µ–∫—Ç—Ä–æ—ç–Ω–µ—Ä–≥–∏—é ‚Äì Prime Business Africa
title_en: Trade Unions Will Start Protesting On Monday Against The Increase In Electricity Tariffs ‚Äì Prime Business Africa
summary_en:
Nigeria's trade unions are preparing for nationwide protests over higher electricity tariffs.
The price increase has caused discontent among citizens and various organizations.
Unions are demanding the abolition of subsidy-era tariffs and criticizing the decision of the Nigerian Electricity Regulatory Commission.
The Energy minister defended the tariff increase, warning of a possible power outage.
The trade unions insist on the cancellation of the decision, citing dissatisfaction with the current situation and ethical considerations.
NERC announced a slight reduction in electricity tariffs after a week-long ultimatum from trade unions.
Trade unions are mobilizing their members for large-scale protests, calling on other sectors of society to join the demonstrations.
Civil society groups are supporting the protests, condemning government policies that are exacerbating the plight of Nigerians.

title_en: Transport: Chemnitz City Railway expects new strikes
summary_en:
After the strikes of the machinists on the Chemnitz city railway, there is no clarity for passengers.
The break, which began on Wednesday afternoon, ended on Thursday at 9:00 a.m.
The company's management expects the next call for a strike in the near future.
The GDL train Drivers' union wants to start with a 35-hour work week.
Relevant agreements have already been concluded with more than 40 railway companies across the country.
The City Railway, which serves six lines in Chemnitz and its surroundings, is categorically against this.

title_en: Quebec Nurses Union resumes pressure tactics and abandons strikes ‚Äî for now
summary_en:
The Quebec Nurses Union is resuming pressure tactics to get a new contract.
The medical staff will come to work every Tuesday in black clothes with the inscription "y'a des limites".
Pressure tactics will be symbolic, strikes are not being used yet.
Negotiations on the conclusion of the contract continue after the rejection of the agreement in principle by ordinary members of the trade union.
The main stumbling block in the negotiations is the possibility of transferring nurses to other departments or medical institutions.
FIQ requires clarity from the government regarding the flexibility of allocating responsibilities from nurses.

title_en: As the crisis in Tunisia worsens, lawyers are on strike because, according to them, an arrested colleague was tortured
summary_en:
Tunisian lawyers are protesting against the recent arrests of their colleagues.
The demonstration took place a few days after the arrest of two lawyers.
Both lawyers were charged with violating the Cybercrime Act.
The National Bar Association called for nationwide strikes and organized a "day of anger."
Protests against civil rights have become commonplace after the Tunisian parliament was frozen.
The speed and number of arrests this week marked a new stage in the crackdown on dissidents.
The Bar Association claims that one of the arrested lawyers was tortured.
The Government denies that Zagrub was tortured and says the arrest was carried out lawfully.
